nodes. 15:14 15:14 See [/BACKUP/20190322/DB_BACKUP_*/*.backuplog] for 15:14 detailed output of backup command execution. 15:14 15:14 db-backup completed at: Fri Mar 22 15:14:02 EDT 2020

section.title: Description
section.p: The db-list tool lists the records in the Aerospike database and the listing is written into compressed (.gz) files in a JSON format.

Following guidelines are applied for the usage of the tool:
This tool is relevant to the ME only. Any data that the tool is meant to dump is not present on the SM.
The db-list tool is installed only on the AdminCLI pod. Nokia recommends you to run the db-list tool only in low business or low traffic hours.
Only one instance of the db-list tool can be executed at a given time. The tool cannot be executed in case a similar tool (for example, db-backup, db-restore, asbackup, or asrestore tool) is currently running on the AdminCLI pod.
Nokia recommends to ensure that the db-list tool or any other similar tool is not concurrently running on other nodes.
The data is spread over two Aerospike sets related by a club-id.
Nokia recommends you to use the db-list tool when database updates in the system are minimum and the database updates happen due to activities like provisioning, on-call traffic, or audit are minimum. Once the db-list tool has been started for execution for a specific set and that set fetches objects from another set, the time elapsed between fetching information from these two sets might lead to inconsistent data.
For instance, to dump all data related to a device, the device is read from one set and then its custom data, aggregate view instances, and bucket instances among others are read from different set. If it takes x amount of time (usually in milliseconds for each entity) to dump the same data then, for instance, if any provisioning activity or 4G or 5G call or audit are ongoing during the same time frame then data dumped might be inconsistent. The case may arise where subscription id is read from device data and by the time tool tries to read the subscription object, it may already have been deleted from the database due to any activity mentioned above.
The db-list tool always starts from the beginning and there is no option to pause or resume a previous tool invocation. This means that, if the db-list tool is interrupted due to any reason or exception, then when the tool is executed next time, it starts from the beginning. The data files created before interruption needs to be manually deleted from the system.
Edigest is dumped with each <entity> option.Edigest is a primary key that uniquely identifies a record in the Aerospike database within a given namespace. Primary key is used in application, while the digest is used for addressing the record in the database.
In order to dump all policy and charging sessions, run the db-list tool separately for all policy and charging sessions../db-list -l policysessions ./db-list -l chargingsessions
In case of dump taken from a system having a larger data size provisioned, for example millions of devices with all associated charging data, then the following options in db-list tool are helpful:
t : number of threads
q : worker queue capacity (it is fixed to 100k records at present)
r : JVM heap size (it is 2G at present) For more information, see the Troubleshooting appendix of this guide.

section.title: Syntax
section.p: Log into the standby AdminCLI pod as the tpaadmin user and type the db-list command:db-list [-l <entity>] [-s <primary|all>] [-n <namespace>] [-m <max>] [-o <dir>]
None of the options mentioned in this command are mandatory.
The tool can be launched without any options. If this occurs, then it uses the default value for each option.

row.entry: Displays the type of entity for which you need records listed. Only one entity at a time can be added in this argument. For example, -l <devices>

entry.p: Default value of this option is -l devices.

The -l <entity> option of the db-list tool has the following output:
-l devices: Lists the devices in the InfrequentlyChangingData set along with the custom data, device subscriptions, subscription counter, associated bucket instances, threshold instances, account balance data, cap instances, device counters, Aggregate View (AV), and DPU present in the DynamicData set.
Edigest is present for device, custom data, subscription, subscription counter, device counter, AV instance, DPU, account balance, and for bucket instance at CS level.
-l accounts: Lists the accounts along with the account administrator present in InfrequentlyChangingData and custom data attributes of the account present in the DynamicData set.
-l users: Lists the users along with the custom data attributes of the user present in the InfrequentlyChangingData and DynamicData set respectively.
Edigest is present for user and custom data associated with account.
-l groups: Lists the groups in the InfrequentlyChangingData set along with the custom data, group subscriptions, associated bucket instances, subscription counter, threshold instances, cap instances, group and device_group counters, aggregate view, and account balance data present in the DynamicData set.
Edigest is present for group, custom data, subscription, subscription counter, group counter, AV instance, device group counter, account balance, and for bucket instance at CS level.
-l sysessions: Lists only the sessions of Sy type present in the SessionContainer set.
-l afsessions: Lists only the sessions of Af type present in the SessionContainer set.
-l ucs: Lists all the records present in the UsageControlService set.
-l allsubscriberdata: Lists all the subscriber entities data (which includes, devices, groups, users, and accounts).
-l gysessions: Lists all the Gy sessions present in the DynamicData set.
-l imssessions: Lists all the IMS sessions present in the DynamicData set.
-l ratingsessions: Lists all the rating sessions present in the DynamicData set.
-l chargingsysessions: Lists all the Sy sessions present in the DynamicData set.
-l chargingsessions: Lists all the charging sessions (Gy, rating, IMS, and Sy) present in the DynamicData set.
The primary option lists only the records that are primary to this site and the all option lists all devices.

This option is applicable only when the listed object is one of devices, accounts, users, or groups. This option is ignored if the value is not one of the values for devices, accounts, users, or groups.

row.entry: Default value is primary. Lists primary or all
The Aerospike namespace to look in for the records.

entry.p: The namespace should be a partitioned namespace. For example, the namespaces starting with the spspd prefix.
If all is specified, then the tool lists from all the partitioned namespaces.

row.entry: The maximum number of records to be listed.

entry.p: If all is specified, then the tool does not stop until it has processed all of the records.
The output directory where the listed records are placed.

In the specified directory, the tool creates a new directory bearing the name of the selected object type and the current timestamp.
Ensure that you have sufficient disk space in the file system mount where the output directory is located.
Ensure that the user used to execute the tool has write permissions on the specified output directory.

row.entry: Displays the number of processing threads.

entry.p: Default value is equal to half the number of CPUs or VCPUs on the node.
A high number of processing threads increase the CPU utilization of the node. On the other hand, a lower processing thread count may engage Aerospike query threads for longer durations.
Nokia recommends you to select the number of processing threads nearest to the number of CPUs.

row.entry: Displays the number of out files.

entry.p: Default value is equal to the number of processing threads.
Nokia recommends you to keep the number of out files the same as the number of processing threads.

row.entry: Displays the capacity of queue in thread pool.
Displays the heap size (in MB) for database dump process.
This option is set depending upon the available RAM.
Forces the db-list tool to execute on the AdminCLI pod.

section.title: Example
section.p: Output similar to the following screenshots appear when you run the db-list tool as a root user with no arguments:
The tool asks for a confirmation before proceeding with its task.
The tool also prints progress in terms of the number of records processed after every 30 seconds.

section.title: Description
section.p: This command displays Aerospike database statistics, including the number of records, memory usage, disk usage, local cluster data migration, and cross site data replication.
There is a summary view that would be a typical starting point. There are also more verbose views available for drilling further into the per-node statistics.
This tool can be executed on the AdminCLI pod at any time.

p.codeblock: db-stats -s <set> [-i] [-c] [-o <dir/file>] db-stats -v <stat_type> [-s <set>] [-o <dir/file>] db-stats -l [-o <dir/file>]

row.entry: Specifies the set (or table) to display, or all to display statistics for all sets.
Include a count of total Inactive records (tombstoned).

Configuration sets. The output will also include the site/system configuration data sets. This option can be used only with -s all and cannot be used with verbose mode. The results will be different depending on whether it is used on an ME or SM.
Lists Session Counts. The operation may take a while to complete.

Specifies the output directory and filename to append the DB stats output. This is written in append mode to enable a periodically-scheduled running of this command (e.g. daily) to form a historical view. For the current directory, use ./<file>

entry.p: Verbose mode for a given stat type, showing stats for each node in the DB cluster.
Note: For large DB clusters, the verbose output may be quite long.

Stat type may be:
records: Record counts. When this stat type is used, the -s <set> is also required.
memory: Memory and disk usage.
migrate: Local cluster data migration.
repl: Cross site data replication.
all: All of the above stat types, for -s all

section.title: Example Output
section.p:
The following explains the output of db-stats:
Record count summary: Every record appears in the system two times (replication factor is two). The total unique record counts shown take this into account, and divides the total record counts by the replication factor to display a total unique record count.
Namespace: The record count summary has column headings for the namespace of the various data sets.
Namespaces have the following meaning:
spspd<id>: This namespace contains the SPS ME partitioned data that is replicated to one other SPS ME site in the network. Each namespace is replicated to a different SPS site.
spsglobal: Data in this namespace is replicated to all other SPS MEs in the network. This namespace includes routing/mapping data for locating the Home SPS ME for any given record.
spslocal: Data in this namespace is configured locally on this SPS and is not replicated to any other SPS sites.
sps: Data in this namespace is configured on SM and pushed to SPS ME. It is not replicated to any other SPS sites.
Unknown: If a database node does not respond to the statistics query, its status is displayed as Unknown. When this happens, the unique record count totals are only approximate.
Grp: DB nodes are grouped into two groups, with one copy of each record existing in Group 1 and the other copy in Group 2.
Data migration: When a database node cluster changes (e.g. a DB node fails, or a DB node recovers, or a DB node is grown into the system), the database may initiate automatic migration of replicated partitions amongst the DB nodes in this local system to maintain the replication factor and the balance across nodes. During this migration period, the unique record count totals are only approximate and are likely underestimated.
Data migration, Xmit: Total number of partitions pending to be sent out to others from this node. Will be 0 in a normal steady state.
Data migration, Rcv: Total number of partitions being received from other nodes at this moment. Will be 0 in a normal steady state.
Total Unique Records: The number of unique records, which in a normal system in steady state, is equal to the total records divided by the replication factor. (For example, if there are 1,000 total records and the replication factor is 2, then the actual number of unique records is 500, with there being 2 copies of each record).
Active Records: The number of unique active records. Active records are the only ones that are visible and accessible to provisioning and application processing. (Active records are those that have not been recently deleted and therefore do not have any temporary tombstone records remaining in the database).
Inactive Records: The number of unique inactive records. These are records which have been deleted but for which a tombstone remains in the system.
Cross site data replication: This is the replication of data across SPS systems in the operator network. Various metrics are reported for this replication, including:
System metrics:
Digest log records: Number of records logged into digest log.
Digest log free %: Percentage of the digest log free and available for use.
Digest log relogged: Number of records relogged into the digest log due to temporary issues when attempting to ship.
Metrics per remote data center:
State of the remote DC: Values can include UP, DOWN, INACTIVE, or WINDOW_SHIP.
In flight: Number of records that are in flight (which have been shipped but for which a response from the remote DC has not yet been received).
Ship ok (K): Number of records that have been successfully shipped, in thousands.
Ship err dest: Number of errors from the remote destination cluster(s) while shipping records for this DC. Errors include out-of-space, key-busy, etc.
Ship err src: Number of client layer errors while shipping records for this DC. Errors include timeout, bad network fd, etc.
Ship (MB): Number of Megabytes successfully shipped.
Time lag: Time lag for this specific DC. The timelag represents the time (in seconds) it took the latest successfully shipped record from the moment it was first written at the source until it was successfully shipped to the destination cluster. Another way of saying this is the difference between the current time and the times stamp of the record which was last successfully shipped (each record written at the source is time stamped as it gets written into the replication digestlog). When having multiple destination DCs, this represents the maximum time lag across all those remote DCs. Under normal operations, though, the timelag for each DC will be the same, given that the DB ships records in lock-step. The timelag at each DC would be different when a DC is down or in the CLUSTER_WINDOW_ SHIP state.
Avg latency: Moving average latency in milliseconds to ship a record to remote SPS sites.

The counts are grouped by primary site ID.-sh-4.2$ db-stats -l Date: Wed Sep 19 10:11:30 EDT 2018 It may take a while to query and aggregate the session counts. Please wait... Site ID 1* 2 IP-CAN 9799587 9799587 Af 0 0 Sy 0 0 Sd 0 0 S9 0 0 NASReq 0 0 Gy 0 0

section.title: Description
section.p: The log-level command provides you with get/set/reset log levels from the AdminCLI pod to all application servers in the cluster. This tool helps you get/set/reset log levels without any modification in log4j.xml.

You can easily switch back and forth from the following:
TRACE
DEBUG
INFO
WARN
ERROR
FATAL

section.title: Syntax
section.p: To get the level of a logger:log-level [-n <hostname>] [-p <port>] <logger name>
To set the level of a logger:log-level [-n <hostname>] [-p <port>] <logger name> <level>
To reset the levels of all loggers or a specific logger back to default:log-level [-n <hostname>] [-p <port>] -r [<logger name>]

If the hostname is not specified, the command will be run against all application servers. Changing the logger level using this utility does not persist after an application server restart. For a persistent change, add a "logger" entry in log4j.xml.
Code Description
No arguments Displays usage/help information.
-h Displays usage/help information.
-n <hostname> Indicates the server host name. The -n option allows you to indicate the specific application server you want to run the logging against.
-p <port> Indicates the server port number. The default port number is 3334.
<logger name> Provides the logger name.
<level>
Indicates the logging level. INFO, TRACE, DEBUG and WARN.
Valid values for the logging levels are:
TRACE
DEBUG
INFO
WARN
ERROR
FATAL
-r <logger name> Resets the levels of all loggers or sets a specific logger back to the default.

section.title: Usage
section.p: To get the level of a logger:
For the "get" operation:

A value of 'null' means that a level has not been explicitly set for the given logger. When a level of 'null' is obtained, a recursive attempt is made on the parent logger in order to determine the inherited log level.
For the "set" operation:
A previous level of "INFO" is assumed if a level has not been explicitly set for the given logger.
For the "reset all" operation:
If no loggers need to be reset, the log4j.xml configuration file will be read and any changes from the file will be applied.

section.title: Examples
section.p: The following shows some examples of where the set and get operations are used.

p.codeblock: -sh-4.2$ ./log-level "com.alcatel.tpapps" DEBUG sps-me-diameter-0: Logger 'com.alcatel.tpapps' set to 'DEBUG'. sps-me-diameter-1: Logger 'com.alcatel.tpapps' set to 'DEBUG'.
-sh-4.2$ ./log-level "com.alcatel.tpapps" sps-me-diameter-0: com.alcatel.tpapps DEBUG DEBUG sps-me-diameter-1: com.alcatel.tpapps DEBUG DEBUG
-sh-4.2$ ./log-level "com.alcatel.tpapps" TRACE sps-me-diameter-0: Logger 'com.alcatel.tpapps' set to 'TRACE'. sps-me-diameter-1: Logger 'com.alcatel.tpapps' set to 'TRACE'.
-sh-4.2$ ./log-level "com.alcatel.tpapps" sps-me-diameter-0: com.alcatel.tpapps TRACE TRACE sps-me-diameter-1: com.alcatel.tpapps TRACE TRACE
sh-4.2$ ./log-level "com.alcatel.tpapps" INFO sps-me-diameter-0: Logger 'com.alcatel.tpapps' set to 'INFO'. sps-me-diameter-1: Logger 'com.alcatel.tpapps' set to 'INFO'.
-sh-4.2$ ./log-level "com.alcatel.tpapps" sps-me-diameter-0: com.alcatel.tpapps INFO INFO sps-me-diameter-1: com.alcatel.tpapps INFO INFO
-sh-4.2$ ./log-level "com.alcatel.tpapps" WARN sps-me-diameter-0: Logger 'com.alcatel.tpapps' set to 'WARN'. sps-me-diameter-1: Logger 'com.alcatel.tpapps' set to 'WARN'.
-sh-4.2$ ./log-level "com.alcatel.tpapps" sps-me-diameter-0: com.alcatel.tpapps WARN WARN sps-me-diameter-1: com.alcatel.tpapps WARN WARN
-sh-4.2$ ./log-level -r "com.alcatel.tpapps" sps-me-diameter-0: Logger 'com.alcatel.tpapps' reset to 'INFO' sps-me-diameter-1: Logger 'com.alcatel.tpapps' reset to 'INFO'
-sh-4.2$ ./log-level "com.alcatel.tpapps" sps-me-diameter-0: com.alcatel.tpapps INFO INFO sps-me-diameter-1: com.alcatel.tpapps INFO INFO

section.title: Description
section.p: This tool allows you to get the heartbeat status on demand for remote members and their components. For the local server status, you can enter the AdminCLI floating IP address, or the IP Address of the active AdminCLI and run the network-heartbeat script. As the tpaadmin user, you can run the following from anywhere.

p.codeblock: network-heartbeat [-h]

row.entry: Displays the status of the local site and the status of the remote sites declared in the network topology.

p.codeblock:
Local Status: Component [ME] Service Status [IN_SERVICE]
Status for Site 'SPS-ME2' ID [2] Component [ME] Service status [OUT_OF_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [3596] Missed traffic beats [3596] Last contact [Never] Last attempt [1s ago]

section.title: Description
section.p: This tool displays composite status information for an SPS system. Information includes the site name and the status of all installed components (SM/ME). For each component, each type of service that makes up the component is then listed, indicating how many instances are configured, and of those, which ones have a status of UP or DOWN.For SPS-SM nodes, it is the intended behavior that if the SPS-SM status is down, the Provisioning port remains up and ready to process incoming REST requests. For SPS-ME nodes, it is the intended behavior that if the SPS-ME status is down, the Diameter port remains up and ready to process call.

This tool may be run on an SPS that has only the SM or ME component installed, or on an SPS that has an integrated SM/ME system (IG). Output will differ based on the installed components.This tool will query the system monitoring service running on the active Central Management pod. At least one Central Management pod must be up and running along with the SDC/ETCD component.

section.title: Syntax

p.codeblock: sps-status [-h][-j]

section.p:
Where:
No arguments Displays usage/help information.
-h Displays usage/help information.
-j This option outputs status in JSON form.

section.title: ME Output Description
section.p:
The following terms may be seen in the output for an ME:
Site Name: This displays the name for this SPS system site.
Component ME State: This displays the component for which the status is collected.
State: This displays the composite state for this SPS component. This is the state that is used by the heartbeat mechanism for communicating status with others in the network. Possible values are UP or DOWN.
Active SM: This displays the name of the active SM serving this ME.
Service: The type of service. A service may have multiple instances in the site, configured as STANDALONE, ONEPLUSONE, or NPLUSK. The summary table shows the composite state for each service, as well as the total configured instances, and the number that are UP and DOWN.
AEROSPIKE_CLUSTER: The Aerospike cluster is the SPS database.
CDR: The Charging Data Report node for Charging Data Reports and Call Detail Reports.
CHARGING: Charging application.
DIAMETERIO: Input/output on the IOHD for Diameter traffic.
ETCD_CLUSTER: The distributed key-value store.
HTTPIO: Input/output on the IOHD for http/2 traffic.
KAFKA: A distributed messaging platform, for handling various real-time events. The Kafka health monitor runs on the active OAME. At a high level, It periodically produces and receives messages from Kafka. If multiple attempts are unsuccessful, the monitoring system will mark the service as down.
LOADBALANCER: The load balancer on the IOHO of the ME.
LTM: Lock and Transaction Manager, which secures locks for database access and provides transaction management for data integrity.
NOTIFICATION: The Notification server is a non-vital service that is part of the Common Services node. It sends smart notifications to end users based on predefined notification templates selected after ART rule evaluation. It receives triggers from SPS applications (Charging, Policy) and other applications (for example, SurePay, external PCRF) for sending notifications.
POLICY: Policy application.
PROVISIONING: Part of the Common Services node, responsible for carrying out all the provisioning work of SPS.
ROLLBACK: Rollback manager is part of transaction manager, responsible for rolling back database transactions in case of failures.
ROLLBACK: Rollback manager is part of transaction manager, responsible for rolling back database transactions in case of failures.
TRSCHEDULER: As part of DB Layer it is used to control the DB background I/O intensive activities to minimize I/O spikes and optimize database performance.
XDR: The cross-data-replication (XDR) from the database.
State: Displays the state for this service. Possible values are UP or DOWN.
Vital: States whether or not the service is required; each service is described as vital or not, 'vital' meaning a problem with the service can put the site out-of-service.
Mode: States whether the node is configured as STANDALONE, 1+1, or N+K.
Instance: Identifies the instance, whether it is up or down, and for 1+1 configurations, displays whether it is the Active or Standby. The ACTIVE/ACTIVE and STANDBY/STANDBY instance for SM NPLUSK configuration shows whether the SM is acting as the Primary or Secondary SM. This information is used by Ud plugins for processing various types of Ud distributions.
Composing States: Composing states are taken from multiple monitoring jobs to detect some soft failure scenarios at the container level. These soft failure scenarios impact the ability to provide adequate service. If there are any container-based composite statuses in the monitored items that are DOWN, then the instance status will also be DOWN. These composite states provide insight as to what actions are required to recover the container and allow the SPS to provide adequate service. These composing states can include:
whether the service is UP or DOWN
whether the aerospike client is UP or DOWN
whether the ltm client is UP or DOWN
Whether the service instance status is UP or DOWN does not have a bearing on whether the component is In-service; however, if there are enough instances that are DOWN, the component status will eventually be DOWN or Out-of-service as well.

section.title: SM Output Description
section.p:
The following terms may be seen in the output for an SM:
Site Name: This displays the name for this SPS system site.
Component SM: This displays the SPS component type.
State: This displays the composite state for this SPS component in the site. This is the state that is used by the heartbeat mechanism for communicating status with others in the network. Possible values are UP or DOWN.
GeoRole: This displays whether or not this SPS component is ACTIVE.
Service: The type of service. A service may have multiple instances in the site, configured as STANDALONE, ONEPLUSONE, or NPLUSK. The summary table shows the composite state for each service, as well as the total configured instances, and the number that are UP and DOWN..
AEROSPIKE_CLUSTER: The Aerospike cluster is the SPS database.
CKEY_CLUSTER: The CKEY monitoring service status. CKEY service running on IOHO nodes is a service monitored from the AdminCLI pod at specified intervals with the default interval being every 5 seconds. CKEY is available on the SM components list only. CKEY is not available for ME deployments where SM is not available.
CMDB_CLUSTER: The MariaDB (CMDB) monitoring service status. CMDB instances running on IOHO nodes are monitored from the AdminCLI pod at specified intervals with the default interval being every 5 seconds.
ETCD_CLUSTER: The distributed key-value store.
KAFKA: A distributed messaging platform, for handling various real-time events. The Kafka health monitor runs on the active OAME. At a high level, It periodically produces and receives messages from Kafka. If multiple attempts are unsuccessful, the monitoring system will mark the service as down.
LOADBALANCER: The loadbalancer on the IOHO of the SM.
LTM: Lock and Transaction Manager, which secures locks for database access and provides transaction management for data integrity.
SM: The Service Manager server.
TRSCHEDULER: As part of DB Layer it is used to control the DB background I/O intensive activities to minimize I/O spikes and optimize database performance.
XDR: The cross-data-replication (XDR) from the database.
State: Displays the state for this service. Possible values are UP or DOWN.
Vital: states whether or not the service is required; each service is described as vital (true) or not (false), 'vital' meaning a problem with the service can put the site out-of-service.
Mode: states whether the node is configured as STANDALONE, ONEPLUSONE, or NPLUSK.
Instance: Identifies the instance, whether it is up or down, for NPLUSK displays Active/Active, or Standby/Standby, and for 1+1 configurations, displays whether it is the Active or Standby.
Composing States: Composing states are taken from multiple monitoring jobs to detect some soft failure scenarios at the container level. These soft failure scenarios impact the ability to provide adequate service. If there are any container-based composite statuses in the monitored items that are DOWN, then the instance status will also be DOWN. These composite states provide insight as to what actions are required to recover the container and allow the SPS to provide adequate service. These composing states can include:
whether the service is UP or DOWN
whether the aerospike client is UP or DOWN
whether the ltm client is UP or DOWN

section.title: Description
section.p: This command displays XDR metrics along with both standard and internal XDR status. This tool can also be used to override the XDR states of OOS-WFR and OOS-DRR.

row.entry: Displays XDR metrics and status for the local site and the remote sites.
Allows you to set the OOS-DRR override value, which can be true or false.
Allows you to set the OOS-WFR override value, which can be true or false.

p.codeblock:
[tpaadmin@sps-centralmanagement-0 bin]$ xdr-status Date: Thu Jun 18 22:30:43 UTC 2020 XDR replication status (local site towards remote sites): ------------------------------------------------------- Not applicable/available.
XDR replication status (remote sites toward local site): ------------------------------------------------------- Not applicable/available.
Overall States: --------------- Service State: UP Internal service state: Current
